title: High broker fees: how to avoid being stung when investing in trusts
text:
Investment trusts have a lot of things going for them but are high charges from brokers stopping investors buying them?

Unlike funds, investment trusts are listed on the stock market and are therefore priced as stocks, which are typically more expensive to buy and sell on fund shops.

Yet they have, on average, returned more than their open-ended fund rivals over the long term and usually have a cheaper management fee.

Oft-forgotten about, broker costs can eat into returns and led Telegraph Money reader Ronald Veitch to ask whether it was viable for him to invest in trusts at all given that he has a smaller amount to invest.
